@graph.d3f:definition: The detect tactic is used to identify adversary access to or unauthorized activity on computer networks.
@graph.rdfs:label: Detect

@graph.d3f:definition: Actively collecting PKI certificates by connecting to the server and downloading its server certificates for analysis.
@graph.rdfs:label: Active Certificate Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Detection of unauthorized use of administrative network protocols by analyzing network activity against a baseline.
@graph.rdfs:label: Administrative Network Activity Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Collecting authentication events, creating a baseline user profile, and determining whether authentication events are consistent with the baseline profile.
@graph.rdfs:label: Authentication Event Thresholding

@graph.d3f:definition: Collecting authorization events, creating a baseline user profile, and determining whether authorization events are consistent with the baseline profile.
@graph.rdfs:label: Authorization Event Thresholding

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing sequences of bytes and determining if they likely represent malicious shellcode.
@graph.rdfs:label: Byte Sequence Emulation

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing Public Key Infrastructure certificates to detect if they have been misconfigured or spoofed using both network traffic, certificate fields and third-party logs.
@graph.rdfs:label: Certificate Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Comparing client-server request and response payloads to a baseline profile to identify outliers.
@graph.rdfs:label: Client-server Payload Profiling

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing failed connections in a network to detect unauthorized activity.
@graph.rdfs:label: Connection Attempt Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Determining which credentials may have been compromised by analyzing the user logon history of a particular system.
@graph.rdfs:label: Credential Compromise Scope Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Analysis of domain name metadata, including name and DNS records, to determine whether the domain is likely to resolve to an undesirable host.
@graph.rdfs:label: DNS Traffic Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing database queries to detect [SQL Injection](https://capec.mitre.org/data/definitions/66.html).
@graph.rdfs:label: Database Query String Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Monitoring the existence of or changes to Domain User Accounts.
@graph.rdfs:label: Domain Account Monitoring

@graph.d3f:definition: Executing or opening a file in a synthetic "sandbox" environment to determine if the file is a malicious program or if the file exploits another program such as a document reader.
@graph.rdfs:label: Dynamic Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Emulating instructions in a file looking for specific patterns.
@graph.rdfs:label: Emulated File Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Monitoring the security status of an endpoint by sending periodic messages with health status, where absence of a response may indicate that the endpoint has been compromised.
@graph.rdfs:label: Endpoint Health Beacon

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing the files accessed by a process to identify unauthorized activity.
@graph.rdfs:label: File Access Pattern Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: File Analysis is an analytic process to determine a file's status. For example: virus, trojan, benign, malicious, trusted, unauthorized, sensitive, etc.
@graph.rdfs:label: File Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Identifying and extracting files from network application protocols through the use of network stream reassembly software.
@graph.rdfs:label: File Carving

@graph.d3f:definition: Employing a pattern matching rule language to analyze files.
@graph.rdfs:label: File Content Rules

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing the properties of file create system call invocations.
@graph.rdfs:label: File Creation Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Employing file hash comparisons to detect known malware.
@graph.rdfs:label: File Hashing

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing the behavior of embedded code in firmware and looking for anomalous behavior and suspicious activity.
@graph.rdfs:label: Firmware Behavior Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Monitoring code is injected into firmware for integrity monitoring of firmware and firmware data.
@graph.rdfs:label: Firmware Embedded Monitoring Code

@graph.d3f:definition: Cryptographically verifying firmware integrity.
@graph.rdfs:label: Firmware Verification

@graph.d3f:definition: Comparing strings using a variety of techniques to determine if a deceptive or malicious string is being presented to a user.
@graph.rdfs:label: Homoglyph Detection

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing standard inter process communication (IPC) protocols to detect deviations from normal protocol activity.
@graph.rdfs:label: IPC Traffic Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing identifier artifacts such as IP address, domain names, or URL(I)s.
@graph.rdfs:label: Identifier Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing inbound network session or connection attempt volume.
@graph.rdfs:label: Inbound Session Volume Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing vendor specific branch call recording in order to detect ROP style attacks.
@graph.rdfs:label: Indirect Branch Call Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Operating system level mechanisms to prevent abusive input device exploitation.
@graph.rdfs:label: Input Device Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Detecting anomalies in user access patterns by comparing user access activity to behavioral profiles that categorize users by role such as job title, function, department.
@graph.rdfs:label: Job Function Access Pattern Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing local user accounts to detect unauthorized activity.
@graph.rdfs:label: Local Account Monitoring

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing a call stack for return addresses which point to unexpected  memory locations.
@graph.rdfs:label: Memory Boundary Tracking

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing email or instant message content to detect unauthorized activity.
@graph.rdfs:label: Message Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing intercepted or summarized computer network traffic to detect unauthorized activity.
@graph.rdfs:label: Network Traffic Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Establishing baseline communities of network hosts and identifying statistically divergent inter-community communication.
@graph.rdfs:label: Network Traffic Community Deviation

@graph.d3f:definition: The operating system software, for D3FEND's purposes, includes the kernel and its process management functions, hardware drivers, initialization or boot logic. It also includes and other key system daemons and their configuration. The monitoring or analysis of these components for unauthorized activity constitute **Operating System Monitoring**.
@graph.rdfs:label: Operating System Monitoring

@graph.d3f:definition: Collecting host certificates from network traffic or other passive sources like a certificate transparency log and analyzing them for unauthorized activity.
@graph.rdfs:label: Passive Certificate Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Detecting anomalies that indicate malicious activity by comparing the amount of data downloaded versus data uploaded by a host.
@graph.rdfs:label: Per Host Download-Upload Ratio Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Cryptographically verifying peripheral firmware integrity.
@graph.rdfs:label: Peripheral Firmware Verification

@graph.d3f:definition: Monitoring platform components such as operating systems software, hardware devices, or firmware.
@graph.rdfs:label: Platform Monitoring

@graph.d3f:definition: Process Analysis consists of observing a running application process and analyzing it to watch for certain behaviors or conditions which may indicate adversary activity. Analysis can occur inside of the process or through a third-party monitoring application. Examples include monitoring system and privileged calls, monitoring process initiation chains, and memory boundary allocations.
@graph.rdfs:label: Process Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Comparing the "text" or "code" memory segments to a source of truth.
@graph.rdfs:label: Process Code Segment Verification

@graph.d3f:definition: Identification of suspicious processes executing on an end-point device by examining the ancestry and siblings of a process, and the associated metadata of each node on the tree, such as process execution, duration, and order relative to siblings and ancestors.
@graph.rdfs:label: Process Lineage Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Detects processes that modify, change, or replace their own code at runtime.
@graph.rdfs:label: Process Self-Modification Detection

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing spawn arguments or attributes of a process to detect processes that are unauthorized.
@graph.rdfs:label: Process Spawn Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Collecting network communication protocol metadata and identifying statistical outliers.
@graph.rdfs:label: Protocol Metadata Anomaly Detection

@graph.d3f:definition: Monitoring the activity of remote procedure calls in communication traffic to establish standard protocol operations and potential attacker activities.
@graph.rdfs:label: RPC Traffic Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: The detection of an internal host relaying traffic between the internal network and the external network.
@graph.rdfs:label: Relay Pattern Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Detection of an unauthorized remote live terminal console session by examining network traffic to a network host.
@graph.rdfs:label: Remote Terminal Session Detection

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing the resources accessed by a user to identify unauthorized activity.
@graph.rdfs:label: Resource Access Pattern Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Analysis of source files, processes, destination files, or destination servers associated with a scheduled job to detect unauthorized use of job scheduling.
@graph.rdfs:label: Scheduled Job Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing the execution of a script to detect unauthorized user activity.
@graph.rdfs:label: Script Execution Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Characterizing the reputation of mail transfer agents (MTA) to determine the security risk in emails.
@graph.rdfs:label: Sender MTA Reputation Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Ascertaining sender reputation based on information associated with a message (e.g. email/instant messaging).
@graph.rdfs:label: Sender Reputation Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing changes in service binary files by comparing to a source of truth.
@graph.rdfs:label: Service Binary Verification

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing the duration of user sessions in order to detect unauthorized  activity.
@graph.rdfs:label: Session Duration Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Comparing a call stack in system memory with a shadow call stack maintained by the processor to determine unauthorized shellcode activity.
@graph.rdfs:label: Shadow Stack Comparisons

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing system calls to determine whether a process is exhibiting unauthorized behavior.
@graph.rdfs:label: System Call Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Tracking changes to the state or configuration of critical system level processes.
@graph.rdfs:label: System Daemon Monitoring

@graph.d3f:definition: Monitoring system files such as authentication databases, configuration files, system logs, and system executables for modification or tampering.
@graph.rdfs:label: System File Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Cryptographically verifying installed system firmware integrity.
@graph.rdfs:label: System Firmware Verification

@graph.d3f:definition: Analysis of any system process startup configuration.
@graph.rdfs:label: System Init Config Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Determining if a URL is benign or malicious by analyzing the URL or its components.
@graph.rdfs:label: URL Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Analysis of user behavior and patterns for the purpose of detecting unauthorized user activity.
@graph.rdfs:label: User Behavior Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing the amount of data transferred by a user.
@graph.rdfs:label: User Data Transfer Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Monitoring geolocation data of user logon attempts and comparing it to a baseline user behavior profile to identify anomalies in logon location.
@graph.rdfs:label: User Geolocation Logon Pattern Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Analyzing modifications to user session config files such as .bashrc or .bash_profile.
@graph.rdfs:label: User Session Init Config Analysis

@graph.d3f:definition: Monitoring changes in user web session behavior by comparing current web session activity to a baseline behavior profile or a catalog of predetermined malicious behavior.
@graph.rdfs:label: Web Session Activity Analysis
